executive_summary: Indoor cycling studios have faced declines over the current period. The outbreak of COVID-19 hammered indoor cycling studios as social distancing and temporary closures led to a drop in memberships. Following the reopening of the economy and vaccine rollouts, pent-up demand led to strong growth in 2021. Still, indoor cycling studios have not fully recovered from pandemic-induced declines over the current period. The rise of at-home cycling classes like Peloton greatly hindered the recovery of indoor cycling studios as many consumers opted to continue using these services even as the economy reopened. Also, the growing popularity of other exercise classes has subdued growth. Revenue has been decreasing at a CAGR of 2.3% to total an estimated $4.4 billion in 2024, including an estimated decrease of 0.6% in 2024 alone. Climbing internal competition led many studios to hike wages to attract and retain skilled instructors, hindering profit growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The outbreak of COVID-19 hammered indoor cycling studios
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Indoor cycling studios faced considerable declines in 2020 following the outbreak of COVID-19 as temporary lockdown mandates fully shut studios for much of the year. While some indoor cycling studios began offering online training sessions to stop the bleeding, revenue still plummeted as many consumers began doing other forms of recreation and exercise outdoors amid closures. Some indoor cycling studios lowered prices to retain customers while offering online classes and to attract new customers who canceled memberships as studios began running in person again. While cycling studios enjoyed strong growth in 2021, indoor cycling studios struggled to recover from pandemic-induced declines.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Internal and external competition has ramped up
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Cycling studios have struggled to recover from COVID-19-induced declines because of climbing competition. Many consumers began taking at-home fitness classes with companies like Peloton and continued to use those and not renew memberships at indoor cycling studios. The popularity of other fitness classes like Barre has also taken business away from cycling studios. The increase in popularity of at-home fitness classes and other exercise classes has increased competition among indoor cycling studios. Many cycling studios have looked to differentiate themselves by hiring instructors with various certifications. Cycling studios have hiked wages to attract skilled workers, hindering some profit growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Growth to accelerate over the outlook
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Strong growth in total recreation spending over the outlook period will bolster the performance of indoor cycling studios. Participation in sports continuing to climb will also benefit indoor cycling studios. Expansions in disposable income over the outlook period will greatly benefit indoor cycling studios. Strong growth in disposable income levels will not only increase the number of memberships but also expand consumers' expenditure on other products like food, beverages and merchandise. Despite solid growth, indoor cycling studios will struggle from the pandemic-induced declines as competition remains high.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Indoor cycling studios will look to differentiate themselves
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As competition from other exercise classes and at-home cycling classes continues to ramp up, indoor cycling studios will continue to focus on streaming classes to consumers at home, opening the door to gaining new customers who are too busy to attend class or don't live nearby. Implementing more immersive experiences using virtual reality (VR) technology will enable indoor cycling studios to differentiate themselves. The need for quality instructors will continue to hike wage costs and subdue profit growth.

industry_definition: Indoor cycling studios offer fitness cycling classes using indoor stationary bikes. Indoor cycling studios also generate business through guest admissions and selling other products like merchandise, food and beverages to their members.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: The outbreak of COVID-19 led to considerable declines. Social distancing measures and temporary store closures hammered indoor cycling studios. Some studios began offering classes online to offset some losses.

Indoor cycling studios will return to growth. Strong growth in disposable income and surging total recreation spending will lead to expansions for indoor cycling studios, but they will struggle to recover from pandemic-induced declines.

Cycling studios receive little public assistance. Cycling studios primarily receive private assistance through certifications, continued education and other resources from various programs like Spinning and Schwinn

Cycling studios don't face industry-specific regulations. Cycling studios must obtain business licenses, abide by safety standards, follow insurance requirements and abide by membership and advertising regulations.

Growth from membership fees has stagnated. Despite cycling studios lowering prices following the outbreak of COVID-19, increased competition from substitute exercise classes have hindered the expansion of membership fees.

Consumers aged 50 and older are attending indoor cycling studios more. Classes catered to older demographics, increased health consciousness and greater free time have increased this age group's expenditure on indoor cycling studios.

Cycling studios endure various forms of external competition. Exercise classes like Zumba and barre and traditional gyms are substitutes for cycling studios. Also, cycling outdoors or at home with pre-programmed workouts like Peloton are sources of external competition.

Cycling studios face moderate buyer and supplier power. Buyers' ability to compare the price and distance of studios from their homes is their primary power source. Prices that suppliers charge gyms for new equipment and credit terms from financers are the primary sources of supplier power.

Differentiation is the primary barrier to entry. Start-up costs are moderate, legal hurdles are low and many studios are nonemployers, but it may be difficult to attract students if an established gym exists in an area.
Market share concentration is low among cycling studios. Most cycling studios are nonemployers, limiting the potential accumulation of considerable market share.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market comprises consumers aged 18 and younger attending indoor cycling studios. Most consumers in this market get their exercise through sports and don't tend to attend group exercise classes as much as older demographics. Also, age restrictions for certain consumers in this age group prevent them from attending exercise classes without a guardian.
This market comprises consumers aged 18 to under 35 attending indoor cycling studios.

This market comprises consumers aged 35 to under 50 attending indoor cycling studios. While this market comprises a considerable share of revenue, as many consumers in this age group have the disposable income to attend cycling studios and enjoy the time efficiency of cycling classes, the increase in popularity of substitutes has impacted this market.

This market comprises consumers aged 50 and older attending indoor cycling studios. The low-impact nature of cycling and workouts catered to older individuals have led to growth in this market in recent years. Also, many consumers in this age group enjoy the social aspect of classes, have become more health-conscious and have more free time than younger age groups.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment consists of charges levied on cycling studio subscriptions. The main goal of membership fees is to produce cash flows that cover the cost of amenities at the cycling studio.
Other products that indoor cycling studios consist of meals, beverages and guest admissions.
Cycling studios sell various forms of merchandise, including sweatshirts, t-shirts, tank tops and other items with the studio's logo on them.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Accumulation of considerable market share. The pandemic hindered profit. Some cycling studios reduced membership fees to avoid losing a large number of customers and attract new ones following the outbreak of COVID-19 but failed to regain membership to pre-pandemic levels. The need for quality service hiked wage costs. Increasing internal competition among cycling studios has led many businesses to hike wages to attract and retain high-quality instructors.

basis_points.basis_description: Cycling studios face competition from substitute exercise classes like Zumba, barre, and traditional gyms.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: High Service Standards Pushed Up Wage Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are expected to increase to account for 35.4% of revenue in 2024. While a larger number of cycling studios are nonemployers, wages are high for employers as facilities require constant maintenance, excellent customer service and instructors with certifications. Amid stiff internal competition among cycling studios, many employers have hiked wages to attract and retain skilled instructors, contributing to falling profit. Paying for ongoing training and certifications for instructors have also led to higher wage costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low. Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified. The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served my incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_title: TOTAL RECREATION SPENDING HAS INDUCED VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: Given that taking cycling classes is considered a form of recreation, total recreation spending impacts volatility. Total recreation spending plummeted following the outbreak of COVID-19, contributing to massive declines in 2020. As the economy reopened and social distancing measures eased, total recreation spending surged, leading to a considerable recovery for indoor cycling studios, inducing revenue volatility.

FAQs.question: What is the revenue volatility for this industry?
FAQs.answer: The revenue volatility for this industry is described as VERY HIGH.

FAQs.question: What is the reason given for the high revenue volatility?
FAQs.answer: Total recreation spending has induced volatility. Recreation spending plummeted after COVID-19 outbreak, leading to massive declines in 2020 revenue. As the economy reopened, recreation spending surged, causing a considerable recovery and inducing revenue volatility for indoor cycling studios.

FAQs.question: What is the level of regulation for this industry?
FAQs.answer: The regulation level for this industry is described as LOW and STEADY.

FAQs.question: What is the level of industry assistance for this industry?
FAQs.answer: The level of industry assistance is described as LOW and STEADY.
